title: Doctor Says Trump Exam Was Routine
summary: Physician says Saturday visit was planned and consistent with the regular care Mr. Trump receives throughout the year.. WASHINGTON-The White House sought to tamp down speculation about President Trump's health on Monday, releasing a statement from the president's physician saying that Mr. Trump's unannounced weekend visit to Walter Reed National Military Medical Center was routine.

title: State Department Official Gave Detailed Account of Trump-Sondland Call
summary: EU ambassador told president that Ukraine was willing to start investigations, according to the transcript of David Holmes's testimony. WASHINGTON-A State Department official gave a detailed account to House investigators of a conversation he overheard between President Trump and a U.S. ambassador about investigations the president was seeking in Ukraine, according to a transcript of his testimony released late Monday.

title: Powell Meets With Trump, a Frequent Critic, to Discuss Economy
summary: Mr. Powell spoke with the president-who has attacked the central banker for not aggressively lowering interest rates-after an invitation from White House. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell met with President Trump, who has criticized the central bank dozens of times this year, at the White House on Monday to discuss an economy hindered by faltering global growth prospects.

title: Trump Answer on WikiLeaks in Mueller Report Is in the Spotlight
summary: House lawyer says redacted material could show campaign contacts with the website. The top House lawyer's comments about whether President Trump lied to the special counsel have put the spotlight back on passages in Robert Mueller's 448-page report.

title: U.S. Fails to Counter Chinese Efforts to Recruit Scientists, Acquire Research, Senate Report Says
summary: Criticism falls on science-funding federal agencies, including Energy Department, National Institutes of Health. WASHINGTON-Federal agencies have failed to adequately respond to the threat of Chinese government-funded programs that systematically exploit U.S. research to strengthen China's own economy and military, a new Senate report concludes.

title: Hong Kong Police, Protesters Strain to End Campus Standoff
summary: Scuffles break out as forces surrounding university fire tear gas and water cannon at fleeing demonstrators; some high-school students are allowed to leave. HONG KONG-A standoff between protesters and police at a university here extended into a second night, with police keeping the area on lockdown while refraining from using the lethal force they had threatened, as increasingly militant antigovernment activists battled back.

title: GOP Senator Is Cool on Impeachment Witness Vindman
summary: Ron Johnson alleges some national-security officials resent President Trump's style and have resorted to sabotaging him. WASHINGTON-Sen. Ron Johnson (R., Wis.) said national-security officials, potentially including impeachment witness Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman, have worked to undermine President Trump, as he offered details about his interactions with Mr. Trump and officials related to the Ukraine controversy.

title: Terrified Parents Outside a Hong Kong University Plead to 'Save Our Kids'
summary: Authorities allow school principals to go in and bring out children from their schools early Tuesday morning.

title: An Unlikely Hong Kong Tourist Trap Takes a Hit as Insurers Seek Cover
summary: Lucrative sales channel for large life insurers dries up as Chinese tourists stop visiting-and stop buying products denominated in U.S. dollars. For years, popular stops in Hong Kong for mainland Chinese tourists have included the iconic Victoria Peak and its city views, the family-friendly Disneyland-and the humdrum offices of some of the city's big insurance companies.

title: Indigenous Bolivians March on Capital City
summary: Anger over interim president's perceived cultural insensitivity stokes effort to reinstall ousted Evo Morales. LA PAZ, Bolivia-Thousands of indigenous Bolivians flooded into this capital city of almost a million people on Monday as part of a broader effort to fatally weaken the one-week-old government of interim President Jeanine Añez, in part by depriving it of food and fuel.

title: U.S. No Longer Considers Israeli Settlements Illegal
summary: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo lays out shift in decades of U.S. policy on West Bank settlements. The U.S. no longer will consider Israeli settlements to be illegal under international law, officials said Monday, in a move that formalizes the Trump administration's treatment of the West Bank and shifts decades of U.S. policy.

title: Beijing's Secrets of Xinjiang
summary: Leaked documents reveal repression-and embarrassment.. An extraordinary leak from within China's Communist Party government sheds new light on President Xi Jinping's campaign of repression against Muslim Uighurs in the western Xinjiang region. The scale of the crackdown laid bare, on top of what the world already had pieced together about Beijing's anti-Muslim cultural cleansing, demands a response. The leaks offer clues to what such a response might be.

title: Eric Holder's Gerrymander Doctrine
summary: Watch North Carolina to see how Democrats define 'fair' districts.. Liberals grousing about GOP gerrymanders say they merely want "fair" electoral maps. But they're now putting the lie to that claim by opposing a redrawn House map in North Carolina because it doesn't guarantee them a majority.

title: Purging the Pro-Lifers
summary: Democratic AGs bar anti-abortion candidates from any support.. Anti-abortion Democratic officeholders are about as rare as pandas, but many in their party's leadership won't be satisfied until they're extinct.

title: Bloomberg's 'Stop and Frisk' Apology
summary: New York's ex-Mayor turns his back on his own anti-crime policy.. As New York's Mayor from 2002-13, Michael Bloomberg loved to brag that Gotham had become America's "safest big city." Part of its success, he said, was the New York Police Department's "stop and frisk" policy, which took weapons off the street based on "reasonable suspicion."

title: America's Inner-City Cartels
summary: As activists smear and hinder police, will the nation surrender to the forces of lawlessness?. Headlines were seized this month by the ambush and murder of three American women and six children by drug traffickers in Mexico. Americans were naturally shocked by the brutality of the cartels. But it would be a mistake to think it doesn't happen here. Similarly brutal crimes frequently occur among black Americans in our own cities, generating much less coverage. There are signs that gang violence is rising-and spilling over its boundaries in a way that puts more innocent people at risk.

title: 'Halfway' With Warren Is Too Far
summary: Compromises can be more consequential than they first seem.. She'll only get halfway. That's the consensus on Elizabeth Warren: If the senator becomes president, Congress will wear down her ideological edge and stymie much of her radical agenda. The result won't be something free-marketeers can love, but it will be something they can live with and then undo at a later date.

title: Why Obama Stopped Auditing Medicaid
summary: The share of recipients who aren't eligible has grown sharply since the expansion began in 2014.. Medicaid expansion was a key component of ObamaCare. In 2014 when the expansion started, the feds stopped doing audits of states' Medicaid eligibility determinations. The Obama administration's goal was to build public support for the new law by signing up as many people as possible. Now, after a four-year hiatus, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services have begun auditing program eligibility again. According to a report released Monday, the audits found "high levels of observed eligibility errors," meaning a significant number of people are enrolled in Medicaid who shouldn't be.

title: Is Football Violence a Crime?
summary: NFL assaults have led to lawsuits before. But a prosecutor would have difficulty proving a charge in court.. It was the shot to the head heard 'round the world. In the closing seconds of last week's Browns-Steelers game in Cleveland, Browns defensive end Myles Garrett pulled off Steelers quarterback Mason Rudolph's helmet. Mr. Garrett then swung it at Mr. Rudolph, hitting him in the head.

title: Let Proxy Advisers Do Their Work
summary: Muzzling independent research firms would only reward underperforming CEOs and stifle oversight.. Over decades, my companies created hundreds of billions of dollars of value for shareholders by guiding boards and chief executives through the steps necessary to increase the value of their companies. Holding boards and CEOs accountable-and replacing them when necessary-improves the economy, makes companies more competitive, increases employment, and adds to shareholder value. Disasters like Enron, WorldCom and Tyco are much less likely when investors can subject CEOs and boards to scrutiny.

title: The Attack on Asian-Americans
summary: Progressives call these foes of racial preferences 'the worst kind of Americans.'. Asian-Americans have finally made it in America. How do we know? Not from their wealth or educational achievements, but from the way progressives now target those in the community who believe people shouldn't be judged by skin color. For in so doing, these Asian-Americans have exposed a growing fault line in affirmative-action orthodoxy.

title: 'Agent Jack' Review: Tell It to Hitler
summary: Working undercover, a former bank clerk found apparently ordinary British citizens who were eager to aid the Germans if given the chance.. Hitler's lightning-fast advances across Europe in the early months of World War II led to suspicions that he owed his victories to "fifth columns" of traitors: Nazi sympathizers who compromised their countries' defenses from within through spying and sabotage. Those suspicions-widespread but erroneous-led officials in Britain, including Winston Churchill, to wonder whether the same could happen there.

title: Nations Need Leadership, Not a League
summary: Wilson's international hegemon failed 100 years ago, and today's tries fare no better.. The Senate rejected Woodrow Wilson's Treaty of Versailles for the first time 100 years ago, on Nov. 19, 1919-thwarting his ambition to bring the U.S. into the League of Nations. This wasn't the epochal tragedy that generations of internationalist historians and orators have sometimes made it out to be. The world wasn't ready, and probably never will be, for the great powers to outsource their vital interests to an international organization. Wilson's frantic efforts to buy foreign support for the league by making large concessions to partners like France and Italy left the treaty a grotesque and ultimately unsustainable mix of unrealistic aspirations and sordid political deals.

title: Drug Crime Expert Charged With Laundering Venezuelan Bribery Proceeds
summary: A University of Miami professor, who is an expert on crime in Latin America, was indicted Monday on money laundering and conspiracy charges. A University of Miami professor who has written on organized crime was charged Monday with laundering money from a bribery scheme in Venezuela.

title: TikTok Explores Rebranding to Shake Off Chinese Roots
summary: After a spectacular rise earlier this year, the social-media company finds unease about its Chinese roots may hinder further growth. TikTok this year made history as China's first social-media company to make it big in the U.S. Now, TikTok wants to shed its label as a Chinese brand.

summary: An exhibition celebrates Glasgow's brief decorative-arts dominance. Baltimore

title: Facebook, Censorship and Political Speech
summary: The problem at hand isn't politically incorrect content that might offend American liberals. It entails covert, fraudulent and often illegal campaigns to manipulate public opinion ahead of elections around the world.. Your Nov. 8 editorial "Targeting Mark Zuckerberg" defends Facebook 's stance on political ads. You characterize the push to strengthen regulation of social media as a partisan bid to censor political speech-and President Trump in particular. This represents a gross underestimation of the global threat posed to democracy by online disinformation. The problem at hand isn't politically incorrect content that might offend American liberals. It entails covert, fraudulent and often illegal campaigns to manipulate public opinion ahead of elections around the world. The opacity of these operations makes them useful tools for unscrupulous politicians in various countries, as well as for foreign powers and extremist forces eager to damage democratic institutions.

title: Dreamers' Peril Is the Fault Of the Do-Nothing Congress
summary: President Obama knew he didn't have the power to make an executive action stick, but he did it anyway, because Congress wouldn't act.. President Obama knew he didn't have the power to make an executive action stick, but he did it anyway because Congress wouldn't act. When President Trump came into office he tried to make DACA permanent by urging Congress to pass it into law. The courts, as usual, intervened to stop him and Congress did what it always does, nothing.

title: American Institutions Are Collateral Damage Amid Impeachment Fight
summary: The foreign service, the House Intelligence Committee and the FBI are just some of the important institutions taking body blows right now. To state the obvious, impeachment could hurt President Trump's chances at re-election, even if he survives a Senate trial, if undecided voters conclude that something is rotten at the heart of his conduct. Or it actually may help him by further energizing his base and convincing some wavering voters he has been wronged.

title: Aramco Won't Get Any Help From an Overpriced IPO
summary: By insisting on a high starting price for the Saudi oil giant, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman risks hitting local individual investors. Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is insisting on a high starting price for Saudi Aramco. He may end up with a lot of ungrateful subjects.

title: Baltimore Fights to Clear Massive Backlog of Asbestos Cases
summary: Court's plan would take five years for 30,000 cases; Peter Angelos, Orioles owner and trial attorney, objects. The Baltimore court system is locked in a legal and political battle with a powerful Maryland lawyer who owns the Orioles baseball team over efforts to reduce one of the country's largest backlogs of asbestos litigation.

title: Where Deficits Still Matter: On the Campaign Trail
summary: Democratic presidential candidates pressure each other to say how they will pay for policy plans. WASHINGTON-Federal budget deficits have piled up for years without causing the harm many policy makers and economists feared. But on the 2020 Democratic presidential campaign trail, "How will you pay for it?" is a litmus test and an attack line.

title: Molson Coors Chases Young Adults-And Not Just With Beer
summary: Big brewer invests in L.A. Libations, an incubator of healthy, non-alcoholic beverages. Molson Coors Brewing Co. is pivoting from beer to aloe vera water and turmeric seltzer in a bid to capture younger drinkers who aren't interested in alcohol.

title: Iowa Caucuses Could Expand to Warmer Climates
summary: Satellite caucuses are part of an effort to make the tradition-bound process more accessible. When tens of thousands of Iowa Democrats gather on what is likely to be a frigid night for their state's Feb. 3 presidential caucuses, Allison Engel hopes to weigh in from much warmer surroundings: Palm Springs, Calif.

title: P&G Pursues the Do-It-Yourself Health-Care Business
summary: Procter & Gamble now offers sleep aids and other products for consumers who embrace self-care. Americans' growing fixation on self-care has them spending billions to treat conditions from insomnia to itchy skin without doctors or prescription drugs. Now Procter & Gamble Co. is trying to seize on the trend.

title: Manufacturers Face New Threat From Fracking Slump
summary: Drilling decline means lower sales of machinery, engines and pipe. Slowing shale-drilling activity is the latest damper on U.S. manufacturers that had come to rely on a booming domestic energy market.

title: Stocks to Watch: HP, Medifast, Estee Lauder, Fiat Chrysler
summary: Here are the companies with stocks likely to trade actively in Monday's session. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Monday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: Ford's Big Bet: New Electric SUV to Wear Mustang Logo
summary: As America's enthusiasm for muscle cars wanes, Ford is trying to expand the Mustang name to keep it relevant. LOS ANGELES- Ford Motor Co. is counting on the Mustang name-a badge long worn by its powerful, muscle car-to spark the auto maker's transition to an electric future.

title: HP's Clock Is Now Ticking Faster
summary: By signaling interest in consolidation, HP's rejection of Xerox effectively puts both companies in play. HP Inc. and Xerox Holdings Corp. at least seem to agree on one thing: The printing-and-copying business needs consolidation.

title: India's Economic Malaise May Be Far Worse Than It Looks
summary: Many indicators suggest large parts of the economy are in recessionary territory, adding to years of potential exaggeration. India's economy is growing at the slowest pace in six years, according to official figures. That data is likely to be disguising an even sharper slowdown.

title: Marie Kondo Adds an E-Commerce Shop to Her Site
summary: The soft-spoken force behind 'The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up' is launching an online boutique of lifestyle products-from soaps to ceramics-that have passed her 'joy check'. MARIE KONDO HAS already sold the world on the joy of jettisoning the material possessions we don't love. Now the best-selling author of "The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up" and star of Netflix 's "Tidying Up With Marie Kondo" wants us to buy stuff. Hers.

title: Hong Kong's Protests Won't Derail Alibaba's $13 Billion Listing
summary: Resume Subscription. Almost daily street battles in Hong Kong may paint an unlikely backdrop for what could be the world's largest listing this year. For Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba , though, both the timing and location are good.

title: Yahoo Japan and Chat App Line Agree to Merge
summary: The companies say they aim to leverage each other's large user bases to expand their online businesses. TOKYO-Internet portal Yahoo Japan Corp. and chat app Line said Monday they have reached a basic agreement to merge in a deal that includes a $3.1 billion buyout of Line Corp.'s minority shareholders.

title: The Hyper-Organized Christmas Shopper
summary: Conscientious millennials and bargain-seeking moms are wrapping up their holiday shopping before most people even start. And retailers are pushing promotions even earlier.. For most Americans, the holiday shopping season kicks off on Black Friday. Meghan Schwork will be done by then-she started this summer.

title: Investors Reap Windfall From Former Hartford Financial Unit
summary: Talcott Resolution, which primarily holds variable annuities, has turned around since the financial crisis. Several wealthy families and investment firms have received an early $700 million payout from a once-troubled unit of Hartford Financial Services Group Inc. that has enjoyed a remarkable turnaround since the financial crisis.

title: Hong Kong Protesters' DIY University Armory: Firebombs, Slingshots and Catapults
summary: The atmosphere at Chinese University of Hong Kong was sometimes playful; cars and bikes arrived to drop off siege supplies. HONG KONG-In the run-up to Sunday's fiery confrontation that erupted at a Hong Kong university, the city's youthful pro-democracy protesters occupied several campuses and spent days amassing an arsenal: thousands of firebombs, bricks, bows and arrows, slingshots and catapults.

title: Port Authority Plans to Test Self-Driving Buses
summary: The technology would be aimed at easing traffic on its bus-only lane. Transportation officials are looking to self-driving technologies to help New Jersey commuters reach New York City in one of the nation's busiest bus lanes.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.
